description:
An intensive introductory lecture course covering the cell, molecular biology, biochemistry, and the genetics of animals, bacteria, and viruses. This course is comparable to Biology 101, but places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches. Particular attention is given to the ways in which modern cell biological and molecular genetic methods contribute to our understanding of evolutionary processes, the mechanistic basis of human disease, and recent biotechnological innovations. BIOL 121 and 123 must be taken concurrently. 

Biology Majors and Pre-Medical students should take either BIOL 101 or 121. BIOL 121 is the companion course to BIOL 124 and may be taken before or after BIOL 124.
name: INTRO BIO-MOLEC BIO LIFE

values.comments:
An intensive introductory lecture course covering the cell, molecular biology, biochemistry, and the genetics of animals, bacteria, and viruses. This course is comparable to Biology 101, but places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches. Particular attention is given to the ways in which modern cell biological and molecular genetic methods contribute to our understanding of evolutionary processes, the mechanistic basis of human disease, and recent biotechnological innovations. BIOL 121 and 123 must be taken concurrently. Biology Majors and Pre-Medical students should take either BIOL 101 or 121. BIOL 121 is the companion course to BIOL 124 and may be taken before or after BIOL 124.

Students generally liked this course, calling it “a great intro bio course,” “very well organized,” and of “immense value to anyone interested in the natural sciences.” Several students praised the amount they learned in the course. Students pointed out that recorded lectures were made available online, which made one student remark that there was “no need to go to class.”

The course was taught by four professors, of which one was Professor Rea. Students did not differentiate in their comments about the professors, but remarked that all four professors were “great” and “excellent.”

Students generally remarked that the course was “actually not that hard nor is it that bad,” despite a reputation to the contrary. It “does require quite a bit of studying” and “was still a lot of work,” but was generally considered easier than expected. One student called the class “a very difficult course,” while another noted the “hard grade curve” due to the face that “most kids in the class are bio engineers or advanced biology students.” This review was based on eight student comments.
